title: Undeniable proof that trolls do NOT get banned
body:
I have loved this game for a long time, but over the years the troll problem has gotten worse and worse and Riot has done NOTHING to address it at all. Any effort they make is on banning the people that get frustrated at the trolls and say naughty words. Every time i bring this up though, it is claimed that Riot is banned trolls and that my experiences must be all delusion. 

**So i decided to troll.** I decided to troll every ranked game until i got banned. I used all the trolling techniques. I built as troll as possible intentionally, i purposely fed, i would steal as many kills as possible and then go afk, i would afk farm the jg until my team lost, i would NEVER group with my team, i would ALWAYS steal a role or position in champ select, and then fill it with the worst possible champ, and** i would do anything and everything in my power to make my team have as miserable a game as possible, EVERY SINGLE GAME until i got banned. **
I didnt just play badly, i played intentionally detrimental to my team and their moral. In fact, probably at least 25% of the games, i played good on purpose, only to go afk with all the gold and make my team lose. 

Guess what, 250 ranked games, not a single ban. I ruined the gaming experience for 2,250 players, i negatively impacted matchmaking by single handedly altering the mmr of 2,250 players, i wasted at LEAST 937 hours of other peoples time. The only punishment i received was a chat ban before i started trolling because i was upset i was getting trolled and i got leaverbustered when my entire team lagged out. **But NOT ONE SINGLE PUNISHMENT, or even warning, for trolling the living crap out of everyone all the time. ** 

I did all the things that cause players to hate this game, and made every game i was in miserable, and I'm sure i garnered thousands of reports, but not even so much as a warning. This made me sick to stomach to do, but Riot has continued to deny this is a problem and promote delusional statistics to cover it up, and the only way to prove trolls don't get banned was to become a troll. I didn't enjoy becoming what has caused me so much frustration, but something, something batman quote. 

This is unacceptable, this is atrocious, this is without defense. This account should have been banned within 5 games of trolling. This account should be permabanned, but instead got zero punishment for trolling. 

I'm done with trolling now, i have proven my point. If riot and the community still want to pretend like it isnt a problem, then they can go ahead and let thousands upon thousands of games get trolled every day with no recourse. If Riot wants to read this and then ban my account now, great? But its pointless now, as the damage is already done and i wont be trolling anymore, but at least banning me now would prove they care even a little about trolls. 

It's been 5 full seasons riot, and i have played every one of them, and the troll problem has never been worse. The only difference is now i know if i dare say a word to the trolls, i'll get banned. I would be really curious to know how many players got banned for raging on me during those 250 games, but im sure that would just make me that much more disgusted with you. 

tl;dr - I trolled 250 ranked games with no punishment to prove Riot does absolutely nothing to address trolls.

Edit: I just want to point out that someone from Riot saw this and decided "naw, let him go, he doesnt verbally abuse his teammates so its cool"

I think you misunderstand my point.

You claim that you've proven that Riot doesn't ban trolls - as in, they ban zero trolls. But you have a sample size of **one troll**, which is not *nearly* a large enough sample size to make such a sweeping claim. What you have truly proven is that their system is not 100% effective (because a single contrary sample is all that's necessary to contradict an absolutist statement).

If we expand that sample to **two** trolls - by adding the OP of [this thread](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/1cvmXAWA-permanently-banned-never-said-a-word-no-email) - we suddenly see a 50/50 ratio (and has the side note of being the single contrary sample necessary to contradict your own absolutist statement).

To be **very** clear, I am not saying that Riot bans half of all the trolls out there. I don't know what the actual success rate is, there, and I wouldn't try to imply otherwise. I simply wish to emphasize this point: *arbitrarily small sample sizes yield results that can be extremely misdirecting*.

So what do these cases show with certainty? Only that Riot's system is neither an absolute failure, nor an absolute success. As with most things, it lies somewhere between - though where, exactly, would require **significantly** more data to determine.

It's important to recognize that *to Riot*, there's only one troll. One account. One player. One set of reports. One case. Ergo, one troll.

Your sample size of trolls is 1. Out of 67+ million players (0.0000014925% of the total). Pretty small sample.

But if you want to talk about your sample size of *trolled games*, we can do that, too. But first, to establish some baseline comparisons:

Assuming ~30 minutes per game, your 250 games covers 125 hours, or about 5 days (rounded down).

There are approximately 27 million players active each day. I'll arbitrarily assume they play an average of 1.5 games, giving us a rough estimate of 40.5 million games per day. Assuming you played all 250 games consecutively (an obviously false assumption that leans in your favor), over the course of your 5 days of trolling, we have a total of 202.5 million games.

So your sample size of *trolled games* is 250 out of 202.5 million games (0.0001234568% of the total). Larger, but still incredibly small.

---

If you don't mind, I'm going to close with this final statement: Please stop assuming that simply because I'm pointing out a flaw in your logic and conclusion that I **disagree** with you.

For the purposes of posting here, I *do not care* whether you are right or wrong. I do, however, care that your premises and arguments do not support your conclusion. Because only by *recognizing* that, can you seek to rectify it, thereby strengthening your position.

They've had automated systems in place for a while now to catch verbal abuse and leavers/afks. The systems have become pretty efficient, and will dole out bans fairly quickly.

In-game behavior is a lot more difficult of a task, but they are rolling out an automated system to catch some forms of in-game trolling. There are so many ways to go about this, though, that the system will still be learning for quite some time.

In many cases, in-game behavior isn't paired with any admission or evidence in the chat. So the system can only rely on reports to build up cases against these people. And even then, it can be difficult to prove after-the-fact. Frankly, the best way to figure this out would be to actually go back and watch the matches in question.

Also, I would believe that people are more likely to report somebody on their team after a loss than a win. People tend to want to blame the loss on something, and reporting a troll or toxic player is a good way to vent that energy. After a tough win, they might just be relieved enough at the win that they leave the post-game chat quickly and forget to report.

But like I said, the systems to detect problematic in-game behavior are rolling out now, and will continually improve. The reason they catch more verbal abuse is because it's easier to detect more quickly because they have an established system in place that's fairly efficient at catching these. Would you prefer that they had waited to launch any automated system at all, until they had one set up to detect each possible scenario?

How about over a year ago when if you got reported for trolling enough you would go to the tribunal and punished by your peers? Then they removed it. 

If you think its because riot is "working on it" and just doesnt have the time or resources to roll it out yet, you are naive and delusional. They have intentionally removed systems of detecting trolls with nothing added to help it. 

But the game has existed for 7 years, lets get real, if they wanted to have a system to detect trolls, they would at least have something by now.

The tribunal was a very important development by them back when they did it. But currently it would have a bit less purpose. Data from the tribunal is what Riot used to help develop the automated systems that have replaced it at this point. And when they bring it back in the future, that'll probably still be the main purpose. 

We have automated systems in place to handle the 'easy' cases. The verbal abuse, the negativity, even the times where players announce they're going AFK or feeding or whatnot. But the Tribunal was *never* good at dealing with toxic gameplay patterns. Once again, these are the sort of thing where you'd really have to be there to verify that it happened. Best-case scenario, you would have some context in chat by the other players (preferably the other team), and maybe some comments put in by those who reported. But comments were few and far between in the tribunal, so it's far from reliable. 

But now, they've been able to analyze enough gameplay data in these scenarios to be able to start automatically detecting toxic gameplay as well. And it's taken this long because they want to be as careful as possible to eliminate false positives by the system. 

They haven't had the staff for 7 years to tackle these kinds of things. Probably only the last 3 or so, realistically. And it takes a LOT of data, data analysis, and development to build a system that picks up the subtleties of toxic vs. regular gameplay with no false positives. If you think it's that easy, apply for a job with Riot and you can build the system for them.

I regularly voted in the Tribunal back when it was up. I saw cases where people had been reported for in-game actions rather than chat. Intentional feeding in extreme cases was easy to catch. Instances where the person announces their intentions in chat are easy to catch. But there were some where it was just impossible to tell. *If* I was lucky enough to have several descriptions of the behavior included in the reports, sometimes I would vote to punish if the behavior seemed consistent across all or most of the games in the case.

But I can tell you that in many cases, those last ones were the types of reports that were getting a pass in the system. Because there simply isn't any evidence in the limited amount of information available in a tribunal case. 

Also, they recently rolled out [automatic detection for intentional feeding](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/miscellaneous/i5yNt3I5-upgrading-the-intentional-feeder-detection-system), so actually, you can't tell me that they're *not* doing anything.

Other trolling behavior is on their radar as well. But it's going to be extremely complicated to automatically distinguish between trolling and behavior that's okay. Were those two people running double-jungle for fun, or did somebody have their role 'stolen' in champ select, so they just decided to take a jungler and follow the other guy the whole time? Is that duo top lane a strategic pick, or did somebody get left with the jungle position after calling top, and they refused to take it? Is that Bard intentionally ulting his allies to prevent them from doing productive things or not?

In the meantime, the best way to detect this sort of thing is really with manual reviews of the games in question, which is largely up to Riot to do. The good thing, though, is that with automated systems in place for catching many other types of behavior, they might have more time to try to deal with these cases of trolling.

I mean, what's your goal here anyhow? A congratulations that you proved that Riot doesn't have a system in place to catch a behavior that they've never claimed to have systems in place for?
